snippet: Bo Xilai, Communist Party chief of Chongqing, had been a contender for the Standing Committee of the Politburo, a nine-member body that effectively runs the country.
abstract: Bo Xilai, the brash Communist Party chief of the Chongqing municipality in China’s southwest, is removed from his post, an unmistakable sign that scandals have put an end to his political ambitions and complicated the national leadership transition that will take place in the fall; his troubles began last month when his handpicked police chief, Wang Lijun, sought refuge in the United States Consulate in Chengdu.

byline.contributor: Jonathan Ansfield and Mia Li contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Bo Xilai, Communist Party chief of Chongqing, had been a contender for the Standing Committee of the Politburo, a nine-member body that effectively runs the country.

headline.seo: In China, Bo Xilai Ousted From Communist Party Post
headline.main: Upstart Leader in China Is Ousted From Party Post
headline.print_headline: Upstart Leader in China Is Ousted From Party Post
